episode.title: G. M. Leasing Corporation v. United States

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Court will hear arguments first this morning in No. 75-235, G.M. Leasing Corporation v. the United States.
Mr. Leedy you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I am Richard Leedy from Salt Lake City, Utah.
This case before the Court involves the Internal Revenue Service seizure of assets pursuant to a jeopardy assessment.
The question upon which this Court has granted certiorari was whether or not such seizures have violated the Fourth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.
The petitioner in this case G. M. Leasing Corporation had all of its assets seize pursuant to such a jeopardy tax assessment and as a result, it dealt the debt now to the Corporation.
Those assets consisted of several luxury automobiles including four Stutz automobiles, two Rolls Royces and a Jaguar.
Additionally a bank account was seized from G.M. Leasing Corporation together with all of its books of records.
The petitioner was a family owned corporation and was a new or start-up corporation that was incorporated for the purpose of leasing luxury automobiles.
At the time of the seizure the petitioner had not yet engaged in the business of leasing, however, taken many pre-requisite steps in order so to do.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: No, Your Honor I do not believe so they cost approximately $40,000 a piece.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The contemplation was nonetheless these were going to be leased?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, I think it was going to be worldwide Your Honor.
In fact, two of these Stutzs were seized from Los Angeles, California.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy

turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or anything else?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Well, they had obtained the lease forms, they were preparing the cars for lease; they had not yet have them for that amount of time and they had negotiated to acquire a showroom, they had obtained lease forms, they contacted prospective lessees, they contacted other dealerships to see if they could obtain cars at a discount price for leasing.
But Your Honor it is correct they had not yet leased any cars.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And had they any employees?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: The record shows they had no employees.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How recently had the company that incorporated?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: My recollection Your Honor, I am not positive, but I think it was within the year.
There is no question that the petitioner G.M. Leasing Corporation was a family corporation and primarily controlled by an individual by the name of George I. Norman, Jr.
Mr. Norman was a businessman in Salt Lake City, Utah and he have substantial income and substantial wealth.
Throughout the briefs in this case Mr. Norman is referred to as the taxpayer, and a taxpayer he was.
In 1970 one of the years under consideration in this case he paid estimated taxes of $290,000.
Because of his income and high expenses Mr. Norman was in the state of constantly undergoing IRS Audits.
In fact, he had undergone an audit from the years 1963-1968 and the IRS Auditor was one particular agent by the name of Bill Clayton.
The evidence of the trial showed that an animosity had developed between Mr. Norman and Mr. Clayton.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Is Mr. Norman a fugitive now?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Does this bring into play possibly the Molinaro doctrine, you know the Molinaro case?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I am not certain of that doctrine Your Honor.
Mr. Clayton was the IRS Auditor who prepared the assessments in the Hester case.
In March of 1973, the taxpayer George I. Norman, Jr. became a fugitive from Justice.
Several years prior to his becoming a fugitive he was convicted of the federal crime of aiding and abetting a willful misapplication of bank bonds.
He was sentenced to two years in prison and through the course of several years, he had appealed his conviction.
In March of 1973, his appeals were exhausted and he was required to surrender himself to begin serving his prison term.

He did surrender himself to the Marshals in Denver, Colorado, and after surrendering himself he asked permission to make a telephone call, The Marshal released him to go down the hall to a payphone and he never returned.
He left his family and his home, and incidentally he left his assets behind him.
Mr. Bill Clayton, the evidence showed had been working on Mr. Normanâ€™s 1970 and 1971 taxes since October prior to his fugitive status in March.
Several weeks after Mr. Norman became a fugitive, Mr. Clayton prepared a statutory notice of deficiency for Mr. Normanâ€™s 1970 1971 taxes.

He then recommended that this assessment to be a jeopardy assessment, and he finally recommended that the petitioner G.M. Leasing Corporation be considered the alter ego nominee or transferee of George I. Norman.

In accordance with those recommendations, the IRS issued a jeopardy assessment and made demand upon Mrs. Norman, the taxpayerâ€™s wife for the payment of approximately $1 million dollars in taxes, penalties and interest.
Mrs. Norman who was not accustomed to her husbandâ€™s business, she was merely a housewife suggested that the IRS agents see her husbandâ€™s attorney.
Rather than so doing the IRS Agentâ€™s next step was to start seizing assets.
Their first move was against the bungalow in Salt Lake City, Utah, which was known throughout the briefs in the trial as the Cottage.
The Cottage was the office of the petitioner, it was also the office of George I. Norman and it was also the residence of George Normanâ€™s son the intervener in this action.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Leedy, you are referring to Mr. Norman and petitioner as if they were two separate entities.
You take issue with Tenth Circuitâ€™s finding that one with the alter ego or the other.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I certainly do, I would rather adopt the trials courtâ€™s finding that they were not alter ego or nominee status.
The Internal Revenue Service broke the locks on the building known as the Cottage and entered and began searching.

Upon their entry, one of their group Chiefs realized that it was a residence as well as an office, and based upon his own testimony he said he was fearful of violating someoneâ€™s constitutional rights.
And therefore, he replaced the locks and left the premises.

Two days later, the Internal Revenue Service agents again broke into the cottage and they seized the entire cottage including the real estate and including the contents of the cottage, which included the books and records of the petitioner.
The IRS at that time also seized all of the assets of petitioner, which consisted of luxury automobile as well as the bank account, its books and records.
Petitioner brought suit in the United States District Court for the District of Utah for wrongful levy pursuant to statute 26 United States Code Section 7426.
The District Court found in petitionerâ€™s favor there was not an alter ego nominee or transferee of George I. Norman, Jr. that the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed.
The second aspect of the petitionerâ€™s claims in the District Court was that the assessment was arbitrary and capricious.
Petitioners sought an injunction against the collection of tax and the seizure of assets.
The Court may wish to note that last term we decided the Shapiro case, which I believed, had almost an identical, factual connotation as the Hester case.
In the Hester case, the petitioner attempted to discover the basis underlying the tax assessment, which was done in Shapiro.

In so doing, we took the deposition of the District Director of the Internal Revenue Service in Salt Lake City and in Shapiro case written by deposition, the taxpayer proceeded by way of written interrogatories.
Under advice of Justice Department Council, the District Director refused to answer any questions concerning the tax assessments.
Two reasons were given for the refusal.

The first one is rather ironic because they refused to give us information about the tax assessment because we do not have the taxpayerâ€™s consent; if they had seized all of our assets to pay for the taxpayerâ€™s taxes.

The second reason for refusing to answer the question was the same reason given in Shapiro, that the anti-injunction act applied and there was no jurisdiction in the District Court to restrain the collection of taxes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In your view the counsel who was in court, before court in that proceeding if the taxpayer was a fugitive?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: The petitioner whose assets have been seized Your Honor he was seeking to obtain the return of his assets.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you say the petitioner and he?
Will you clarify precisely whom you mean?
Would you designate the name of the person you are referring to?
You are referring to the Corporation now?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I was referring to the District Director refusing to answer the questions, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I am asking you who was in the court on behalf of the taxpayer.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Myself.
Well, I was on behalf of the petitioner who was not the taxpayer.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think that is what gives rise to some problem perhaps.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You do not claim that you have contemporary authority from your client who is a fugitive to you, Mr. Norman.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I have his Power of Attorney, Your Honor, and I do represent him in tax court.
But in this particular case, there is no appearance for him and he is not involved in the case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, in his absence who is running the Corporation?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: His son, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is he a party to this?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: He became an intervener when they seized certain assets of his own.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did he have to intervene, if he represents the Corporation?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: The Corporation brought suit on its own name, Your Honor, for the assets that were seized from the Corporation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And if that was his Corporation, he would not have intervene, wouldnâ€™t he?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: My belief that the Corporation has a standing of its own to bring its own lawsuit, for the loss of its assets.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, this is a one man corporation -- is the Corporation a fugitive too?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, supposing on, and levying on the Corporation, how would you?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: You would give notice to its officers and directors I believe.
They were at that time, that is in the record.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They are what, who?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: There were three individuals, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You keep saying â€˜wereâ€™ -- I am asking, are the officers as of today?
You do not really know, do you?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, I do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, is the Corporation had meeting?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, it has, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Without the President?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: He is no longer President -- the fugitive, you are talking about, he is no longer the President, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was that in his record?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I believe it is, yes, Your Honor.
His son took over and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He is a fugitive in the record.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, but I believe the evidence showed that the son testified at the District Court level.
He testified that he was one of the stockholders, together with his brothers.
My recollection is that a meeting was held after the disappearance of his father where his mother, himself and his aunt were elected to the board of directors.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What position does his mother has?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I am not certain, but the officers said she is the Director.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is she the one that told the agent she had nothing to do with the Corporation, she was just a housewife?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Leedy, any claims of Norman III, the son, are not addition here are they?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: No, Your Honor, he also prevailed in the District Court and the government, did not appeal as the decision in his favor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: One last question, precisely where the automobiles when they were seized?
They were on the street, they were in the lot or where?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: There were two in a parking lot in Los Angeles.
There were two -- the remainder when various garages -- is my recollection in Salt Lake City, Utah.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: The evidence showed Your Honor that when the IRS agents visited the house, there were some in the driveway.
I do not believe the seizures of the automobiles were made while they were in the driveway.
They were made from various garages, Your Honor and two were in Los Angeles, California in a parking lot.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Were all of them aware of the that?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I do not believe so, Your Honor.
I could be wrong.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But this case -- whether in the street or whether in the garage.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Not as I view it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Well they did for those -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One or the other (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Now the door that they removed the locks on, Your Honor had to do with the office building where they went in and took the records of the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Seized on the public streets?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I did not say that, I said I did not know, Your Honor, I did not believe so.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, donâ€™t you know the record?
Oh, you want me to -- okay, I will check.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Leedy, one last question and I will stop bothering you.
Do you conceive that the documents have been returned and the copies destroyed as the government charges here?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where they the documents of the petitioner here, the Corporation or of Mr. Norman?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: My understanding is every document that was seized was returned, including those of petitionerâ€™s.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And do you think that a corporation has the same rights under the Fourth Amendment as an individual?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I believe the previous cases of this Court tell that, Your Honor.
My recollection is the Silverthorne Lumber Company case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you rely on Silverthorne?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I rely on it for the proposition that a corporation has a Fourth Amendment right to privacy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And yet, the Solicitor General has not said that in his brief?
Maybe we will ask him why.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: To please the Court, at the trial we attempted to attack the assessment that had been given because the government had counterclaim for foreclosure upon the assets.

We had showed that the Auditor had failed to include in his computations the fact that the taxpayer had paid $290,000, that he had included in the assessment some $115,000 in income that really was an income and that through as prior audits of the taxpayers, he knew that the taxpayer had high business expenses but yet he took no steps to find out what the business expenses were.

Again the Trial Court ruled in favor of the petitioner under the theory that there is a presumption of correctness as to an assessment but that the evidence that weâ€™ve brought forth had rebutted that presumption of correctness, and that shifted the burden to the government to show if there were any taxes due annoying at all.
But the governmentâ€™s evidence was in somewhat disarray, they could not lay a foundation for their exhibits.
They did not have necessary witnesses to testify.
After several attempts, the government rested.
The Trial Court ruled in favor of the petitioner and the Tenth Circuit again reversed saying that we had to show more error than we had to overcome the presumption of correctness.

The final proposition sought by the petitioner in the Trial Court was that the seizure of its books and records, and the seizure of its assets violated its Fourth Amendment rights to the federal constitution.
That is the question upon which this Court granted certiorari.
Again, the Trial Court ruled in favor of the petitioner and allowed us how the damages were permissible but set a hearing date later for the determination of damages.
The Tenth Circuit again reversed that and there was a finding that the one agent had acted with malice.

The Tenth Circuit indicated that they could find no malice in the record and it held that the taxpayers had acted pursuant to statute the levy in the strange statute and that therefore there was no illegal search.

His petitionerâ€™s position that the levy in the strange statute and the jeopardy assessments statute taken together which allows a seizure of property immediately upon an assessment without any notice to the taxpayer and without any pre-determination of probable cause is a violation of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you saying that, is your claim that even if there had been no entry into the corporate premises?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that the seizure of assets itself is protected by the Fourth Amendment to the federal constitution.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think you need a warrant to seize those automobiles for example.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Thatâ€™s what we are arguing and urging this court to dock.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you have another claim that even if that is not so the entry into the premises is?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that a separate matter?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Well, they are inextricably intertwined but I would argue that the entry into the cottage was a search and that by virtue of the fact that there were intelligence agents of the Internal Revenue Service participating -- that by virtue of the fact the documents seized were turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that they were doing more than merely levying, and collecting taxes that they were in fact searching.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose they have found two cars on a public street and two cars sitting in a driveway on private property.
Would you make the same argument about all those cars?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes sir, I certainly would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You do not think that prior cases of this Court wanted the seizure of those four cars that I just described?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: If the Court is referring to the Phillips v. Commissioner case, no, I do not believe so.

If I may distinguish that case, that case involve not a jeopardy assessment but a situation where there had been a determination with both sides participating in the determination of the amount of taxes do annoy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What do you think Shapiro held, you refer to that case?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I think Shapiro held to confine -- I guess the precise holding is the Anti-Injunction Act does not apply to such an extent that the taxpayer cannot challenge the basis for the assessment.
In fact, there is no factual basis underlying the assessment then he is entitled to an injunction to prevent the collection of taxes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think Shapiro recognized that there can be a seizure first and a hearing later?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: That was the precise factual situation in Shapiro, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you are saying that I guess the Court there should not have proceeded on the assumption that the seizure was valid in the first place without a warrant?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I believe that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Was anything that was seized from the house not returned from house or office, what were the items seized from the house or office, the combination, which have not been returned?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: To please the Court, there were many items, which were not the property of the petitioner, which were seized and not returned.
All of the petitionerâ€™s property has been returned, with the exception of the automobiles.
But there were furnishings and furniture and other items that belonged to the taxpayer that were seized to having value and they have not been returned.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And when you use the term â€˜Tax Payerâ€™ you are referring to Mr. Norman the fugitive, as I am taking it.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Leedy, what remains to be adjudicated in this case, the property has all been returned itâ€™s just a quest of damages?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: I believe so Your Honor, the remedy for violation of the petitionerâ€™s rights.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If the damages have remained to be determined, is the judgment below final?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: Well, the Tenth Circuit reversed that judgment, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The judgment, and send it back for retrial on the issue of damages?

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: No, it just reversed it outright and said that there is no liability.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No liability, I see.

turn.speaker: richard_j_leedy
turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
turn.text: To please the Court, I believe in determining whether or not a warrant is applicable to a tax payer seizure.

One might look at the legislative history surrounding the adoption of the Fourth Amendment which I think clearly shows that the tax collectorâ€™s seizure of property was in the contemplation of the framers of the Fourth Amendment.

Most of that legislative history has gone into my opening brief and I would rather than repetitious, I would just simply state that I believe that the legislative history supports the proposition that the seizure of assets by a tax collector is within the meaning of the word â€˜seizureâ€™ of the Fourth Amendment.

The second question revolves around, is once you determine that the tax collectorâ€™s seizure is within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment, the next question is whether or not a warrant should be required before that seizure.
Or whether or not their exigent circumstances precedent, which were dispensed for the requirement of warrant.
It is the petitionerâ€™s position that there are no such exigent circumstances and as the governments position that, there are.
Government cites for support the fact that the tax payer was a fugitive.

The fact that he had not assisted or cooperated in the preparation of his assessment or tax returns and the final reason that certain properties had disappeared, and therefore, they felt their were exigent circumstances which justified the dispensation with the warrant.

I would submit the fact of the petitioner that the tax payers are fugitive, has no bearing on whether or not the collection of the taxes is in jeopardy because all of the assets were left behind that he had no control over the assets.

But even more importantly he had been a fugitive for approximately two-three weeks before the issuance of the jeopardy assessment and there would certainly be time to obtain a warrant within that period of time.
The second question of whether or not he cooperated in the preparation of his taxes, I again do not have any understanding of how that bears upon whether the collection is in jeopardy or not.

But I would submit that the record is devoid of any request on the part of the IRS to obtain his cooperation that in fact the agent himself referred to go to third-party sources to obtain his information about the tax payer.
The final argument, Your Honors, pertaining to this question is the disappearance of property.
You recall the IRS agents entered into the cottage on one particular day and then they left shortly after that.
That time they left men keeping surveillance on the cottage and they observed that evening certain boxes of material being taken by unknown persons.
Two days later or a day-and-a-half later, they then decided to make their seizures.

I would submit number one, that they had already made the determination of jeopardy prior to that occurrence so that could not have been a relevant factor and number two, that within the day-and-a-half period they could have certainly have had time to obtain the detached neutral Magistrateâ€™s decision as to whether or not the man owed any taxes, whether or not those taxes were in jeopardy.

The final argument that the petitioners use is the argument which is often stated in tax cases and that is that the government has a compelling and urgent need to collect his taxes, and therefore, there are exigent circumstances, which would do away with the requirement of obtaining the Magistrateâ€™s decision.
I would submit to the Court that while I have heard that statement made in many tax cases.

I do not know what is so urgent and compelling about the collection of this manâ€™s taxes and finally, I believe in this day and age of budget deficits and deficits spendings that, that while at once may have been an urgent need of the government.
It is no longer such an urgent need, at least no more urgent than the governmentâ€™s need to obtain evidence against criminal suspects.
Therefore, in conclusion, Your Honors, we believe that the entry into the cottage for the purpose of seizing books and records was a search.

We believe that the seizure of assets is also a seizure within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment that therefore the general requirements of the Fourth Amendment should apply that a warrant be obtained and that there were no exigent circumstances in this case which would dispense with the requirement of warrant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Leedy.
Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice may it please the Court.
I would like to return the case somewhat to the issue before which is the validity of these seizures under the Fourth Amendment of the propriety of a jeopardy assessment in this case is not an issue.
Indeed at trial Mr. Leedy had a witness to testify about the jeopardy assessment excluded on the grounds that he was not a contestant.
The propriety of the jeopardy assessment he was contesting the amount of -- so I do not think we need to discuss whether the jeopardy assessment was in itself proper.
I would like to help focus consideration of the case if I discuss separately the three acts of that are complained of.
First the seizure of seven luxury automobiles registered to G.M. Leasing.
Second, the entry upon the premises of the office bungalow.
Third, the seizure of the records along with the other assets remaining in the office.
Considerations affecting the legality of these three acts come without a warrant varies, so I think it is best to discuss them separately.
What I want to say is background that I think it is clear from the record that the IRS had very good reason for what it did in this case.
As the fact show the tax payer, Mr. Norman, had filed a return for 1970 that gave no information whatever from which his correct tax can be computed.
The check he gave in payment of his 1971 tax was dishonored by the bank and Mr. Norman never filed any return for that year.
Now, unreasonably the Internal Revenue Service became concerned about the collection of Mr. Normanâ€™s taxes.

Now, it began to investigate but the investigation formally opened had not moved ahead until in early March of 1973, Mr. Norman became a fugitive from justice after being convicted for misapplication of bank funds.
That caused the service appear they would never recover any of the taxes owed by Mr. Norman and they moved rapidly ahead with their audit.
Now, our brief states and I do not want to correct any wrong implication if there is one that they have received no cooperation from Mr. Norman.

It is quite correct that Mr. Norman was a fugitive from justice and nobody had asked him prior to that time for cooperation after he became a fugitive from justice, they went to third-party sources to develop their information.
But the services sense of urgency was no doubt increased by the fact that it is Agent Applegate testified in the Appendix of page 85.
He said that there had been in this case missing stocks and bonds, shuffling of records, a bank account cleaned out, safety deposit boxes cleaned out, and cars stolen.
So that they were quite concerned about preserving the assets they could still find.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now all of this goes to the reasonableness and validity of the jeopardy assessment which I thought you began by saying, it was not an issue?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I think Mr. Justice Stewart it goes somewhat at least to the reasonable...

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought in this case we began; we proceeded upon the premise that there was a jeopardy assessment and the validity of that assessment is not an issue here.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is quite correct Mr. Justice Stewart.
I was putting this background in my think because it explains the reasonableness of some of the actions that the IRS took in trying to get the property.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you suggesting that there are different gradations of jeopardy assessments?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, no I am not discussing the jeopardy assessment Mr. Justice Stewart, I am discussing the entries and so forth to the background.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is right and we begin then with a jeopardy assessment as a given upon that premise.
You are not going to suggest that this kind of an entry is valid in some kinds of cases where there has been a jeopardy assessment but not in others?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I am going to suggest, I think that the reasonableness of an entry in certain kinds of cases could be drawn into question for outrageous entry, a private residence for example.
It might be a different kind of case, I am just trying to describe the kind of case this is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if the jeopardy assessment were less clearly valid, would this be a different kind of case?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was my question.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I made to describing the urgency which they began to feel about this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I suppose if you needed the -- if the board decides that you needed to enter this premises you are probably suggesting that there is some probable cause.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I am suggesting that Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And do you think that the government needed probable cause to enter these premises?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, if needed probable cause the former probable cause it needed I believe was an assessment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but I asked you whether they needed probable cause.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I do not think so Mr. Justice White unless it needed an assessment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let us assume there is a jeopardy assessment and you say it is valid, assume that.
Now the government is then authorized to enter any private premises of the tax payer whether or not it believes there is property in the premises that they...?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, no, I think they have to have a good faith belief that there is property in the premises.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And assets of the taxpayer?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Assets of the taxpayer, and I should point out that the service, as a matter of policy does not enter private residences if there is any objection unless consent is given.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That policy must be motivated by something.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think it is motivated by --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: By the Constitution?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think it is motivated by their concern that private residences have a much greater privacy interest.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In which Constitution of the United States?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I would think so.
I cannot speak as to the reason why they do the regulations that way, I know they were concerned about the privacy interest whether they were concerned about a Fourth Amendment issue, I do not know.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Your position is still is though that there was no probable cause requirement, to enter the premises of the government, isnâ€™t it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, probable cause varies Mr. Justice White from case to case and I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, whatever it was, you say, you could forget about it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I do not know if we are talking about the same thing, what I am saying is you cannot forget about certain pre-requisites, which may call probable cause.
One is that there is an assessment, and the other is that there is reason to believe, there is property on the premises of the taxpayer, which can be used to satisfy the obligation of the tax.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That much was necessary in any event in effect to enter the premises.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I think, -- yes, if they had no idea whether these premises were the taxpayers or whether there was any property anywhere around, I think that would be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But surely, even so your position certainly is that there was no necessity for any warrant?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Certainly, that is our position.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the probable cause I take it focuses on whether or not there were assets, whether there was probable cause that assets could be discovered on the premises that would satisfy the jeopardy assessment?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes, but I think Mr. Justice Rehnquist, a case when it is the taxpayerâ€™s property, that would almost always be probable cause to think that this building was seized as well.
And there would almost always be probable cause to suppose that there were assets in an office building.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if there were probable cause only to believe that there was evidence but no probable cause to believe that there were assets?
Would your position be any different?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Evidence Mr. Justice Rehnquist of what?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of criminal tax liability.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well the books, the books of the company.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I do not think one could use this kind of entry to secure evidence of a crime were --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but what about the books of the corporation.
Suppose that all (Inaudible) in the house or in the premises with the books, the corporate books?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I think those could be seized for the purposes that the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If you know they were not worth anything, you would not pay any taxes.
It would be the source of information where you could determine the amount of the assessment accurately and where some assets might be?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, let me say two things about that.
There was a later increase in the income for one of these years but that information, that is increase in the assessment, the deficiency, that information did not come from these books or records.
The IRS went in to gather assets, there were books and records, they took them for two reasons.
One reason was they thought that the records might themselves contain assets such as stock certificates.

The other is they thought the records might indicate the location of other property of the taxpayer, and that is not an investigatory reason such as you would have in a criminal case that is simply means of tracking down property, and all of this is taken in that kind of a seizure of records.
It seems to me is a property interest not a privacy interest.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How did they found out that some of the cars were located down in Los Angeles from these records?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not know the answer to that Mr. Chief Justice.
I do not believe they did find it from these records.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: At what stage did the agents observed the apparent surreptitious removal of boxes of materials sometime from the --

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, they made the first entry into the bungalow office on the 21st of March.
They backed out when they saw a stove, a refrigerator because they thought it might be a private residence but it was not.

That night, they saw people carrying boxes of things out of the building, and in the morning, they discovered that the Stutz automobile, which had been in the garage, which they had not seized disappeared, they later recovered that.
It turned out that it was removed by the younger Norman and they later recovered.

But I suppose the automobiles in this case are the most important issues in the Internal Revenue Service, because it seizes assets of that type everyday and it is very important in the collection of taxes.
And I think it would probably impractical, given the dispersion of property that taxpayers mostly have to impose a warrant requirement on that kind of seizure.

For one thing, the Fourth Amendment requires that the places and so forth be described with particularity which means that you have to search for the property then post a guard then go back and get a warrant.
And you have multiple applications in many cases as they kept locating new property, which would also thrust the courts I must say into the day-to-day administration of the Internal Revenues Service.
Now, the core value of the Fourth Amendment, I take it to be the protection of privacy and it seems to me that that value is not even implicated in the process of levying upon automobiles.

The petitioner here makes no point that there was any entry upon any private premises to seize the automobiles and indeed they were found on parking lots and public garages, and I think one of them was found on the streets though, I am not entirely sure.

But there is no privacy interest, the only thing that is at stake here is a seizure for a property interest and the United States has a property interest superior to that of George Norman or his alter ego, the petitioner here.

And that is shown I think by the fact that anything that was seized, which ultimately be held and have been improperly seized, is fully compensable by damages, which an invasion of a privacy interest never is.

And I should note that a full deficiency notice listing issue the items, deficiency has been served upon the taxpayer and that Mr. Norman is now on the Tax Court with his attorney contesting the amount of the deficiency.

I think that is sufficient, it think the automobiles seizure covered by Murrayâ€™s Lessee case which we discussed in our brief and I think it is sufficient to dispose of that issue in favor of the United States.

It is only a property interest at stake, and I think the interest of the Unites States and the flexibility in collecting its efficiency, in collecting amounts due it by delinquent taxpayers fully justifies that.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Would it have made any difference if the automobiles had been on the private property of the taxpayer?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Powell, I think if they had seized the automobile in the garage.

I think that would still have been reasonable and that I think brings me to the question, to the entry into the office because they had to remove the -- they removed the lock on the garage where they are about to seize the automobile when the younger Norman protested.
So they did not seize it.
But had they seized it, I take it there would have been less of a privacy interest in the garage than it would have been if there was any in the office, but I do not think it made any difference.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think it would, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But not in the garage?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not know that I am willing to say that it was not in the garage, but it is slightly the case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it was like the factor --

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, that is quite right.

Now, I think I have discussed the automobile sufficiently, the sheer number of them, the dispersion of them the fact that it is easily movable, the fact that they were not -- they were in public places and so forth.
I think, it sufficiently establishes the reasonableness of that seizure.
Now I want to talk about the second entry into the office.
It is helping to place those evincing context.
I think I briefed us so adequately and I would like to go over the facts about how they discovered that there were such an office and so forth.
I have mentioned that they entered once, saw the stove and the refrigerator and backed out.
Now at that point --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, you mentioned entry into the office.
Should we not for the purpose of the case assume it is a residence?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not think so, Mr. Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It was the residence of the son, was it not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, the record shows, George Norman III, the son, who was 19-years-old at that time, testifies at page 34 of the Appendix, that he had moved in for security purposes because there have been some break-ins.
It was not as if, it was an established residence, he had moved in to protect the office, he was leaving there.
So I do not think that is quite the same or they were near the same as a private interest, and when the office was seized he went back to his father and motherâ€™s house.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, does your argument in this case depend on assuming that it is not a residence then?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think if this were a residence, it would be a more difficult case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I know, but is your argument -- what are you asking us to hold?
Are you asking us to decide a case of a non-residence or decide a rule that will apply to residences as well?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I am asking you to decide the case in reply to a non-residence Mr. Justice Stevens.

I think the degree of residence that was involved here that is that -- which they could not have known, that is that George Norman III, who was 19 had moved in here for security purposes, does not change this into a classic residential dwelling.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If they did not think it was a residence, why did not they continue their total search the first time they entered?
Wasnâ€™t it the policy not to search residences?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is correct, they went in and they saw the stove and the refrigerator and out of abundance of caution went out.
Then two things happened, one was, that they talked to Mr. Red, a Contractor, who said that he had worked in there and it was an office.
The other was that they began to see materials being taken out at night.

Now, the record unfortunately, although we refer to an entrance on the 21st when they backed out and an entrance on the 23rd, if you look at the Appendix Mr. Justice Stevens, it turns out on pages 34, 59 and 77, some people testified that the entrance took place the next day on the 22nd, right after they saw the property being removed.
But other people testify that no, it was the 23rd, and the record is a very unsatisfactory state about that, and nobody, apparently focused on that issue at the trial level.
They went back into the building, but I would place in addition to the circumstances surrounding this.
In addition to the fact that a property interest is at stake and not really a privacy interest.
I think we ought to point out that what was done here follows about 700 years of Anglo-American legal history.
That is at least since the 13th Century, this kind of thing has been regularly done.
At English Common Law, it is quite clear it was done, as our brief describes in the colonies of the United States.

It is quite clear that states such as Pennsylvania and Massachusetts, and others, which had provisions on unreasonable searches and seizures after adopting those prohibitions, adopted statutes that allowed what was done here and much more than what was done here.

So that I think, it is quite clear that the Fourth Amendment was written against the background of English and American legal history and of State Constitutional Law which shows that it was not intended to apply to entries, to seize the property of the taxpayer who was delinquent in order to satisfy his tax obligations.
And I think that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was adopted however against the background of revulsion against writs of assistance and general warrants and specifically against the background of the use of those devises to search to see whether or not a person owe taxes, isnâ€™t that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: To search to see, whether or not a person owe taxes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was a specific background, was it not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: It is quite correct Mr. Justice Stewart, by the writ of assistance, a general writ of assistance was an authority search almost at random to see whether there was property in the houses and had no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Population excise tax should have been paid to do advertising.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is quite correct.
Whereas this is quite different, this is a case in which it has been determined that taxes are owned by a specific person and there is reason to believe that he has property on business premises.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It has been determined unilaterally.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, it has been determined in this case for example after consultation with the Revenue Council, with all the agents, it was quite a federal investigation here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Hasnâ€™t it been determined after any adjudication, which has been determined unilaterally by the collector?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is correct, but that is precisely what has happened throughout our history, from the adoption of the constitution on the First Congress which proposed the adoption of the Fourth Amendment along with the rest of the Bill of Rights of course.
Also passed a statute allowing the stress of the collection of taxes to be levied by the stress on the sale and that contemplated the procedure that was used here.
So I think it is clear that the original understanding of the Fourth Amendment is that this kind of entry was lawful and does not require warrant under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Your position is -- you never need a warrant.
The IRS is involved, you never need a warrant.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not advance the position that brought here today Mr. Justice Marshall.
There maybe circumstances.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I think you are pretty close to it because you had weeks, you had three weeks here.
Didnâ€™t you?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: We had three weeks?
Oh, I see Mr. Justice Marshall.
In this kind of a case in an entry upon business premises, I think the IRS does not need a warrant.
I would not go so far as to make that statement as to a private residence and the IRS does not go so far as to do that kind of thing with private residence.
But I would say that in addition to the practice of the IRS there is much more a stake here.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You see I have trouble with the practical point because it is just as easy to go and get a warrant.
There is no urgency here.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Oh I think there was an urgency once the assessment --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I do not know, I cannot recognize an urgency when you stand for three weeks.
I have great difficulty.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Marshall the assessment was actually made I believe on the 19th, on the next day on the 20th they went to Mrs. Norman and demanded payment.
On the 21st, the seizure of assets began.
So, once the assessment was made --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What was three days?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I have been arguing that, in this case as in the case like Biswell, the operation of the program would be brought to a standstill, if you had to locate a property and then go get a warrant for each item of property particularly describing it --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said that when they knew about these six cars, wasnâ€™t it six?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I believe it was seven but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Seven, when they know about those, could not they have gotten a warrant to seize those?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, they would have the goal for example.
They could not describe where they were until they found them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If they could describe the cars.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes, but if you regard this as a Fourth Amendment search and seizure warrant I would suppose you have to describe their location and so forth.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I just recognize the Fourth Amendment is there, it is my trouble, and I can understand why in certain occasions IRS has a great emergency and the guys at the airport with a bundle of money under their bag may take off.
I would require as to go any place.
But if the man is on his way walking, for three day walk I think you would have time to get a warrant.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think in this case you would have had to locate the automobiles, post guards on each one of them, can go back to the court and get the warrant for the seizure and since there was --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: The record only says â€˜severalâ€™, but they did not --

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: They did not try to seize them that day.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: They did not know who the cars belonged to.
They went back then Mr. Justice Marshall and checked the registration of those cars and found out they belonged to the petitioner.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then they could have gotten a warrant.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork

I am suggesting to you Mr. Justice Marshall that if that requirement were applied across the operations of the IRS which seizes assets everyday --

turn.label: Unknown Speaker

turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork

Pennsylvania, which is 380 U.S. 693 which is a forfeiture proceeding against an automobile where in this Court held that the Fourth Amendment applied when seeking to deprive an owner of the ownership of this property.

I believe that privacy interests are affected when a personâ€™s property is taken away from you.

turn.label: Mr. Richard J. Leedy
